senses.de: To make someone believe that something is true
senses.ex: He tried to convince his parents that he needs a new computer

Tips.title: Emotional Appeal
Tips.description: Use 'convince' when appealing to someone's feelings to believe something.
Tips.example: The documentary convinced me that sea turtles need our help.

Tips.title: Not Always True
Tips.description: Convincing doesn't mean the thing is true, just that someone believes it is.
Tips.example: He convinced the jury of his innocence, even though evidence was missing.

Tips.title: Strong Arguments
Tips.description: When trying to convince, it implies using strong reasons or arguments.
Tips.example: Her speech convinced the council to adopt the policy.

senses.de: To get someone to do something by making them understand and agree with your reasons
senses.ex: She convinced me to start exercising regularly

Tips.title: Action Oriented
Tips.description: 'Convince' can imply persuading someone to take a specific action.
Tips.example: The ad convinced me to try the new burger.

Tips.title: Personal Influence
Tips.description: Often involves a personal interaction or influence to agree with reasons.
Tips.example: My friend convinced me that volunteering is rewarding.

Tips.title: Beyond Facts
Tips.description: Sometimes uses emotional or ethical appeals, not just factual ones.
Tips.example: The charity convinced him to donate with stories of impact.

senses.de: To make someone believe in the truth or value of something
senses.ex: She managed to convince her boss about the value of the project

Tips.title: Reassure Doubts
Tips.description: Use 'convince' to calm doubts or reassure someone about a decision.
Tips.example: I needed to convince myself it was the right choice to move abroad.

Tips.title: Trust Building
Tips.description: Success in convincing can lead to trust in your judgment or expertise.
Tips.example: Her analysis convinced the team she was the right leader.

Assure.wordDefinition:
Assure means to make someone feel confident or certain about something, like a promise or guarantee that something will happen.

For example, "I assure you that the package will arrive tomorrow." This is applicable when you want to give someone the confidence and certainty that something will happen.

Bring around.wordDefinition:
The words bring around and convince both mean to persuade somebody to do or believe something, but they are used in slightly different situations.

Bring around is often used when trying to persuade somebody who is hesitant or opposed to something. For example, if your friend doesn't want to go to a party, you might say "I think it'll be fun; let me see if I can bring you around to the idea.".

Bring around suggests a more reluctant persuasion while convince suggests a more determined persuasion.

Cajole.wordDefinition:
Cajole means to persuade or coax someone into doing something through flattery or gentle pleading. It's usually used when someone is trying to get someone else to do something that they might not want to do, but with a positive approach.

For example, a salesperson may cajole a customer into buying a product by praising its features and stressing how it will benefit them.

So in simple terms, cajole is more about using flattery and persuasion to get someone to do something, while convince is more about using reasoning and arguments to get someone to believe or do something.

Coax.wordDefinition:
Coax means to persuade or encourage someone to do something that they may not initially want to do.

It can involve gentle persuasion or flattery. For example, you might coax a child into trying a new type of food by telling them how tasty it is.

Coax is used when trying to get someone to take a specific action, while convince is used when trying to change someone's attitude or belief about something.

Influence.wordDefinition:
Influence means to have an effect on someone's thoughts, beliefs, or actions.

It can be positive or negative and may not involve changing someone's mind. For example, a friend's positive attitude might influence you to be more positive as well.

Convince involves changing someone's opinion or decision, while influence involves having an effect on someone's behavior or choices, regardless of whether or not their opinion changes.

Persuade.wordDefinition:
The words convince and persuade have similar meanings but they are used in different situations.

Persuade means to make someone believe or do something by appealing to their emotions or desires. For example, you might persuade your parents to let you go to a concert by explaining how much it means to you and promising to be responsible.

You use convince when you want to persuade someone using logic and evidence, and you use persuade when you want to persuade someone using emotions and desires.

Sway.wordDefinition:
The words convince and sway have similar meanings, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Sway means to influence or persuade someone to do or think something by appealing to their emotions or opinions, rather than presenting logical arguments.

It is used when you want to change someone's opinion or decision by appealing to their feelings or values. For example, you might try to sway someone to vote for a particular political candidate by appealing to their sense of justice or fairness.

Convince is used when you want to persuade someone with logical arguments, while sway is used when you want to appeal to their emotions or values to change their opinion or decision.

Win over.wordDefinition:
Convince means to persuade someone to believe or do something, while the phrase win over means to persuade someone to like or be on your side.

If you are trying to win someone over to your side in an argument, you are trying to get them to see your point of view and agree with you.

Convince is more applicable to situations where you are trying to persuade someone to take a specific action, while win over is more applicable to situations where you are trying to build a positive relationship with someone or change their overall opinion of you.
